content.raw:
I switched to `EXPECT_EQ(a, b)` instead of `EXPECT_TRUE(a == b)` in 2270f24, which gives a more informative error message for the homebrew test failure:
~~~
/Users/jenkins/workspace/sdformat-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/sdformat3/src/SDF_TEST.cc:137
Value of: typeid(ignition::math::Pose3d)
  Actual: 16-byte object <70-E4 96-7E FF-7F 00-00 F0-CF D8-00 01-00 00-00>
Expected: poseParam->GetType()
Which is: 16-byte object <70-E4 96-7E FF-7F 00-00 C0-BF E9-00 01-00 00-00>
~~~

content.raw:
Strangely, I get different values for `typeid(ignition::math::Pose3d).hash_code()` in Param.cc and SDF_TEST.cc (see print statements added in a33755d6cdd4):
~~~
Param.cc: 1062a8650
SDF_TEST: 1061d11d0
~~~
Param.cc compiles to the libsdformat shared library, while SDF_TEST.cc compiles to an executable. Are the hash_codes different between shared libraries?
content.html:
Strangely, I get different values for typeid(ignition::math::Pose3d).hash_code() in Param.cc and SDF_TEST.cc (see print statements added in a33755d6cdd4):

Param.cc: 1062a8650
SDF_TEST: 1061d11d0

Param.cc compiles to the libsdformat shared library, while SDF_TEST.cc compiles to an executable. Are the hash_codes different between shared libraries?

content.raw: This is different that any of our other packages. I believe we append the major version to debian package names and homebrew formulae, but the pkg-config and cmake config files always have the same name (ie. `sdformat.pc` or `gazebo.pc`). @\_jrivero_ your thoughts?
content.html: This is different that any of our other packages. I believe we append the major version to debian package names and homebrew formulae, but the pkg-config and cmake config files always have the same name (ie. sdformat.pc or gazebo.pc). @_jrivero_ your thoughts?

content.raw: sdformat and gazebo are in the wrong. The number is needed to support side-by-side installations of a package.
content.html: sdformat and gazebo are in the wrong. The number is needed to support side-by-side installations of a package.

content.raw: Many packages allow side-by-side installation of libraries but not the `-dev` packages. I'd like to hear @\_jrivero_ 's thoughts
content.html: Many packages allow side-by-side installation of libraries but not the -dev packages. I'd like to hear @_jrivero_ 's thoughts

content.raw:
QT is one example. You can install both qt4 and qt5 development side-by-side. 

ROS is another example (a string name is used instead of a number)
content.html:
QT is one example. You can install both qt4 and qt5 development side-by-side.

ROS is another example (a string name is used instead of a number)

content.raw:
good examples.

Those don't upgrade very frequently. I'm not sure how frequently we expect the ignition math API to change.
content.html:
good examples.

Those don't upgrade very frequently. I'm not sure how frequently we expect the ignition math API to change.

content.raw: Ideally very infrequently. I bumped the major version number of ignition-math in this case because ABI changed (private classes added).
content.html: Ideally very infrequently. I bumped the major version number of ignition-math in this case because ABI changed (private classes added).

content.raw:
I agree with Nate here. If the software is designed to be able to be installed side-by-side the different major versions, then we will need different files names.

The same happen with the -dev files. Normally, it is possible to have two libraries installed at the same time, but only one -dev is allowed in the system. Ogre is a good example of this, with two different -dev files for 1.8 and 1.9.
content.html:
I agree with Nate here. If the software is designed to be able to be installed side-by-side the different major versions, then we will need different files names.

The same happen with the -dev files. Normally, it is possible to have two libraries installed at the same time, but only one -dev is allowed in the system. Ogre is a good example of this, with two different -dev files for 1.8 and 1.9.

content.html: We can not get rid of boost yet. Looks like the PKG_DEPENDS variable is not being use in any place in the code.

content.raw: This was suppose to be a list of dependencies that would get processed in `sdf_config.cmake.in`. This would work if each dependency behaved the same, such as using the same format for include directory variables. Since this doesn't work very well in practice, I've broken out each dependency in `sdf_config.cmake.in`.
content.html: This was suppose to be a list of dependencies that would get processed in sdf_config.cmake.in. This would work if each dependency behaved the same, such as using the same format for include directory variables. Since this doesn't work very well in practice, I've broken out each dependency in sdf_config.cmake.in.

content.raw:
I tried to resolve conflicts, and I broke it.
~~~
In file included from /Users/scpeters/osrf/sdformat/src/SDFExtension.cc:18:
/Users/scpeters/osrf/sdformat/include/sdf/SDFExtension.hh:53:13: error: use of
      undeclared identifier 'ignition'
    public: ignition::math::Pose3d reductionTransform;
            ^
1 error generated.
~~~
Should we include `ignition/math.hh` in `Types.hh`? Or should we explicitly include the ignition Pose header in `SDFExtension.hh` instead?
content.html:
I tried to resolve conflicts, and I broke it.

In file included from /Users/scpeters/osrf/sdformat/src/SDFExtension.cc:18:
/Users/scpeters/osrf/sdformat/include/sdf/SDFExtension.hh:53:13: error: use of
      undeclared identifier 'ignition'
    public: ignition::math::Pose3d reductionTransform;
            ^
1 error generated.

Should we include ignition/math.hh in Types.hh? Or should we explicitly include the ignition Pose header in SDFExtension.hh instead?

content.raw: I included the Pose header in SDFExtension, since it's a more minimal inclusion.
content.html: I included the Pose header in SDFExtension, since it's a more minimal inclusion.
